title: Lesson 7: Technologies in Cytology
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding light and electron microscopy techniques, their capabilities, limitations, and applications in cell biology.
learningIntentions: Students can compare light microscopy (LM) and electron microscopy (TEM, SEM) in terms of resolution, magnification, and sample preparation.
Students can calculate magnification and actual size using the formula: Magnification = Image size / Actual size.
Students can select the appropriate microscopy technique for specific investigations.

engagementHook.title: From 200nm to 0.2nm
engagementHook.content: Show the same cell organelle at three scales: light micrograph (blurry), TEM (clear internal structure), SEM (3D surface). 'In 1931, we thought we'd seen all there was to see. Then electron microscopes revealed a world 1000× smaller. Today we can see individual proteins. How do these technologies work, and when do we use each one?'

keyConcepts.definition: The ability to distinguish two separate points as distinct. Minimum distance between two objects that can be seen as separate. Light microscope: ~200nm. TEM: ~0.2nm. SEM: ~3-10nm.
How much larger the image appears compared to the actual object. Calculated as: Magnification = Image size ÷ Actual size.
Uses visible light and glass lenses. Max resolution ~200nm. Can view live specimens, natural colours. Stains enhance contrast.
Electrons pass THROUGH ultra-thin sections. Shows internal 2D structure. Resolution ~0.2nm. Requires vacuum (dead specimens), heavy metal stains.
Electrons scan surface. Shows 3D surface topography. Resolution ~3-10nm. Requires coating with metal (gold/platinum).

misconceptions.misconception: Higher magnification always means better detail
misconceptions.correction: Resolution determines detail, not magnification. You can magnify beyond resolution (empty magnification) but see no more detail.

misconceptions.misconception: Electron microscopes can view living cells
misconceptions.correction: Both TEM and SEM require vacuum and specimen preparation (fixation, dehydration, staining/coating) - specimens are dead.
TEM = internal structure (thin sections). SEM = surface 3D appearance (solid specimens).

contentSections.title: Microscope Comparison
contentSections.note: 1 nm = 10⁻⁹ m. A hydrogen atom is ~0.1 nm across.

contentSections.title: Magnification Calculations
contentSections.content: Formula: Magnification = Image size ÷ Actual size. Units MUST be the same before dividing. Common conversions: 1 mm = 1000 μm, 1 μm = 1000 nm. Scale bars on micrographs can be used: measure bar length, divide by labelled value.
contentSections.example: Image measures 50 mm wide. Actual cell is 50 μm wide. Magnification = 50,000 μm ÷ 50 μm = ×1000.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: A micrograph shows a scale bar labelled '10 μm' measuring 20 mm on the page. What is the magnification?

contentSections.title: Sample Preparation
contentSections.content: Light microscopy: Live cells can be viewed; stains (methylene blue, iodine) increase contrast. TEM: Fixation (preserve structure), dehydration, embedding in resin, ultra-thin sectioning (50-100 nm), staining with heavy metals (lead, uranium). SEM: Fixation, dehydration, critical point drying, coating with thin layer of gold/platinum.

multipleChoice.question: Which microscope would you use to view the 3D surface structure of a cell?
multipleChoice.rationale: SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy) provides 3D surface images. TEM shows internal 2D structure. Light microscopes show 2D with limited resolution.

multipleChoice.question: What is the maximum resolution of a light microscope?
multipleChoice.rationale: Light microscopes are limited by the wavelength of visible light to approximately 200 nm resolution. TEM achieves 0.2 nm.

shortAnswer.question: Compare the resolution and sample preparation requirements of light microscopy and electron microscopy. [4 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Light microscopy resolution ~200 nm; TEM resolution ~0.2 nm
1 mark: Light microscopy can view live specimens; EM requires dead specimens
1 mark: Light microscopy: simple staining; TEM: fixation, dehydration, ultra-thin sectioning, heavy metal staining
shortAnswer.commonError: Confusing TEM and SEM preparation requirements.

shortAnswer.question: Explain why electron microscopes cannot be used to observe living cells. [2 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Electron microscopes require a vacuum (electrons scattered by air molecules)
1 mark: Specimen preparation requires fixation and dehydration (kills cells) / or coating with metal for SEM
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'electrons kill cells' rather than explaining vacuum/dehydration.

definitions: Resolution: minimum distance to distinguish two points as separate.
Light microscope: ~200 nm resolution, can view live cells, natural colours.
TEM: ~0.2 nm resolution, shows internal 2D structure, ultra-thin sections required.
SEM: ~3-10 nm resolution, shows 3D surface, requires metal coating.
Magnification = Image size ÷ Actual size (same units).
keyPoints: Resolution, not magnification, determines visible detail
LM: live specimens, stained or unstained
TEM: transmission through thin sections, internal view

shortAnswer: Light microscopy has a maximum resolution of approximately 200 nm, limited by the wavelength of visible light. Electron microscopy (TEM) achieves much higher resolution of about 0.2 nm. Sample preparation for light microscopy is simple - specimens can be live or dead, and may be stained with dyes like methylene blue to increase contrast. Electron microscopy requires complex preparation: specimens must be dead, fixed with chemicals to preserve structure, dehydrated, and for TEM, embedded in resin and cut into ultra-thin sections (50-100 nm) before staining with heavy metals. SEM requires coating the specimen with a thin layer of metal such as gold or platinum.

Electron microscopes cannot be used to observe living cells because they require a vacuum inside the microscope chamber - electrons would be scattered by air molecules. Additionally, specimen preparation for electron microscopy involves fixation with chemicals and dehydration, which kills the cells. For SEM, specimens must also be coated with a thin layer of metal, which is incompatible with living tissue.
